Hopkins to take larger share of grants for overhead
By BOB DANNER
Hopkins officials plan next
year to take a larger percentage
of the University's federal
research money for overhead
costs.
The rate increase—from 38 to
48 percent—was determined
through negotiations with the
National Institute of Health, the
government agency which
provides the bulk of research
funds.
Some Hopkins faculty
members contend that though
the rate increase is necessary and
appropriate, it is not equitable
under certain circumstances and
may curtail some research
projects already underway here.
Difficulties with the increase
arise from grants issued by the
National Science Foundation,
which adheres to the rates
established by the NIH. Unlike
the NIH, this agency does not
separate indirect cost charges
from the direct costs of the
research effort.
Long term projects which were
planned under the former
overhead charges may be forced
to use the money once
designated for salaries and
supplies to cover this increased
expense.
Dr. John Cebra, Biology,
explained, "I thought that the
increased charges were justified,
but it should only be imposed on

a NSF grant at the time of its
negotiation. If the increase is
levied afterward, it dips into the
direct costs of the project. The
only way out of this is to forfeit
the grant and reapply. At this
time approval rates are very bad
and you could lose your whole
project."
Horatio Proctor, Office of
Sponsored Research, said that if
someone is granted money at one
rate, the University is bound by
that rate and cannot increase it
until he reapplies.
Cebra pointed out, however,
that many projects must submit
budgets each year for approval
and receive an allotmeni that was
fixed when the aim of the
investigation was first delineated
and the grant awarded. These
projects will be subject to the
higher rate even though the funds
provided each year will not
change.
"If operating funds are cut
below a certain level in order to
cover this added expense,
researchers may have to cut back
on their goals. I will probably
have to do this with my project,"
Cebra admitted.
"By placing this high rate on
fixed income grants people will
move to the more health-related

continued.
"NSF grants focus more on

upper limit on funds, cutting into
them will make it difficult to
undertake many projects."

Margaret Mead ends
'Festival of Women'
By LAURA FEIGIN
Margaret Mead will deliver the
final lecture of "Next Step: A
Festival of Woman," presented
by the M. Carey Thomas
Women's Center.
Mead will speak at 8 p.m.
tonight at Shriver Hall on
"Marital Disillusionment: The
Changing Sex Roles."
Co-Director of the Women's
Center Virginia Donovan stated
that Mead was selected for this
program because she "is a woman
who is prominent in her field and
who can certainly be called a
forerunner of the women's
movement."
Mead is a well-known
anthropologist who has done
extensive field work in
non -industrial societies. Her
books on this subject include The
Coming of ike in Samoa, and
Sex and Temperament in Three
Primitive Societies.
Much of this research has led
her to write on the -subject of
changing sex roles. Women's
Center co-director Sue Fino
asserted, "Her work is a great
example for the women's
movement."
Mead has also written
extensively on the dynamics of

social change and the differences
between successive generations.
Her book Culture and Comment
is an explanation of this topic.
Mead's professional and
academic affiliations include the
)ositions of curator emeritus of
!thnology at the American
Museum of Natural History and
Special lecturer at Columbia
University. She has received
eighteen honorary doctorates, as
well as many awards, including
the American Museum of Natural
History Gold Medal and the
Kalinga Prize for the
Popularization of Science,
presented by UNESCO and the
government of India.
This year's "Next Step: A
Festival of Women" was
dedicated to the late poet Ann
Sexton, who was featured in last
year's program, and feminist
scholar Ann London Scott.
Other lecturers in this year's
festival were Bella Abzug, who
spoke on the current political
scene, and Germaine Greer,
whose lecture centered on
women ,and fertility.
Donovan explained that Mead
will round out the program "by
speaking in more sociological
terms."

Senior John Higdon was

Winston Churchill Scholarship
for graduate work at the
Churchill College of Cambridge
University.

master's degrees in Engineering

"I'm really very happy to have
this honor," he said.

Each year 28 of the nation's
top colleges and universities
nominate two students for the
Churchill Scholarship. Higdon
was one of ten students selected
for the award. His acceptance
was based on his formal
application, accompanying letters
of recommendation, and his

the program receive the

The Winston Churchill
Foundation of the United States,

While we realize that the nation's economic woes have
made it necessary for the University's fees and service costs
to increase, the decision to hike the tax on federal research
grants up to 48 per cent gives us cause for concern.
First of all, it is difficult to accept that fact that the
University needs to devote nearly half of its research funds to
"overhead costs."
In addition, we object to the fashion in which this hike
was foisted on faculty members involved in sponsored
research, many of whom may have their projects jeopardized
as a result. Research projects already well underway will have
to face the unpleasant prospect of reallocating their research
grants so that money once used for staff salaries and supplies
can be used to defray the cost of the increased tax.
Though an increase in the University's tax on research
funds may be desirable—if not necessary—from an
administrative standpoint, we consider it grossly unfair that
increased charges should be imposed on a federal grant
subsequent to it negotiation. Some professors may be forced
to cut expenses in their research projects, while others may
be forced to forfeit their grants and reapply later.
When administrative measures such as these impact
adversely on academic pursuits, distasteful things result.
Some faculty have already admitted that the increased tax on
grants will force them to reconsider their research efforts and
"cut back on their goals," in the words of Biology Professor
John Cebra. Also, some faculty may decide to depart for
gentler pastures, where the ratio of research money to
"overhead costs" money is not nearly so excruciating as the
one to one ratio which is planned for next year.

very difficult. Tommy falls into
the category of pop-art, and
subsequently the critics are divided

which goes out of its way to

pop camp which borders on
mindless idolatry.
The key to the film is to
remember that Tommy is pop-art,
and should be judged on that basis,
on the ground of what it sets out
to do. And on those grounds it
works very well; Tommy is

cliches garbed in an artistic
threepiece suit.

but uses them with the subtlety of
a promoter's hype job. In a way, it
is a hype job-the use of colour to

holiday camp become the garb of

handed Christian imagery (when

By JAY GOODGOLD
"When something is raised at a
Board meeting, our presence is
definitely felt," stated Young
Trustee James Shannon after last
week's Board of Trustees
meeting.
This remark, along with similar
opinions from Young Trustees
Michael Hill and Shepard
Hoffman, suggests that the
position, created four years ago
by then-President Milton S.
Eisenhower, is a viable and
productive one.
Colmers
This year's competition for the
position, which ended with the
selection of John Colmers, gave
rise once again to discussion
about whether the Young
Trustees have any real influence
on the Board and whether they
effectively represent the
undergraduate viewpoint.

presence on the Board has both
improved the representation on
the Board, and made the Trustees
more aware of problems facing
undergraduates.
"On matters such as the recent
tuition hike, members of the
Board will turn to us and ask us
questions, or on such matters as
undergraduate issues, William
Harvey [Chariman of the Board
of Trustees] will ask us our
opinion," noted Shannon, a
second year student at American
University Law School.
"One purpose of the Young
Trustee is that we have

the Trustees to solutions from 4,

self-centered," said Hoffman, a
first-year law student at Boston
University.

month, has agreed to take

Hoffman will return in 1976 and
complete the remainder of his

"In our role as Young Trustee,

accepted by the board," said Hill.

since the creation of the position,

Each Young Trustee said,

They said that controversial

"I view the Board of Trustees
as a legislature in that it approves

dissension. They feel that to
agree is an effective role," he
added.
The Board is primarily
concerned with the financial
aspects of the University. As a
result, the Young Trustees are
primarily involved with the fiscal
problems of the University.
Hoffman and Shannon noted
that the regular members of the
Board look to the Young
Trustees primarily in regard to
financial issues.
The Young Trustees, however,
do face some limitations in their
role. Since they are all students
outside of Baltimore, they are
unable to devote their full time
to the position.
"We're not businessmen or
professionals. We try and take
what we believe is the students'
opinion on different proposals
into account at the meetings,"
said Hoffman.
